maml:description.maml:para: Get vegetable objects
Use this command to retrieve vegetable objects from the local computer. The default is to retrieve all objects but you can select them by name or filter for only root vegetables like carrots.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of a vegetable.
Only get root vegetables like carrots or turnips.
The name of a vegetable.
Only get root vegetables like carrots or turnips.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-Vegetable
UPC Count Name State Color --- ----- ---- ----- ----- 4060 13 corn Roasted yellow 4353 9 tomato Raw red 4234 19 cucumber Raw green 4493 8 carrot Raw orange 4107 19 radish Raw red 4329 18 peas Steamed green 4083 17 turnip Boiled purple 4407 13 potato Fried brown 4119 15 broccoli Steamed green 4357 4 zucchini Raw green 4242 7 spinach Raw green 4256 8 cauliflower Steamed white 4028 14 pepper Sauteed green 4448 13 pepper Sauteed red 4254 9 pepper Sauteed yellow 4472 5 eggplant Fried purple

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-Vegetable eggplant
UPC Count Name State Color --- ----- ---- ----- ----- 4472 5 eggplant Fried purple

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-Vegetable -RootOnly
UPC Count Name State Color --- ----- ---- ----- ----- 4493 8 carrot Raw orange 4107 19 radish Raw red 4083 17 turnip Boiled purple 4407 13 potato Fried brown

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 4 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Group vegetables by their CookedState property. Note that the default output is not necessarily the actual property name. You can only see that by using Get-Member.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 5 --------------------------

maml:description.maml:para: Create a new vegetable object.
Use this command to create a new vegetable object. You must specify a vegetable name and color. Note that this command does not write anything to the pipeline unless you use -Passthru.

maml:Description.maml:para: What is the vegetable name?
What is the vegetable color?
How many vegetables do you want? Pick a number between 1 and 20.
Write the object to the pipeline.
Indicate that this is a root vegetable.
What is the vegetable color?
How many vegetables do you want? Pick a number between 1 and 20.
What is the vegetable name?
Write the object to the pipeline.
Indicate that this is a root vegetable.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> New-Vegetable -name leek -color green -passthru
UPC Count Name State Color --- ----- ---- ----- ----- 4069 1 leek Raw green

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> New-Vegetable -name kale -color green -passthru | Set-Vegetable -cookingstate sauteed -passthru
UPC Count Name State Color --- ----- ---- ----- ----- 4302 1 kale Sauteed green

dev:remarks.maml:para: Import a CSV file with headings that match the parameters for New-Vegetable and create new vegetable objects.

maml:description.maml:para: Set a vegetable property

Use this command to set vegetable properties. You can either specify a vegetable by name or pipe objects from Get-Vegetable. By default this command does not write anything to the pipeline unless you use -Passthru.

maml:Description.maml:para: A piped in vegetable object.
Set the vegetable's cooking state.
Set the number of each vegetable. This should be a number between 1 and 20.
Write the object to the pipeline.
The name of a vegetable.
Set the vegetable's cooking state.
Set the number of each vegetable. This should be a number between 1 and 20.
Write the object to the pipeline.
Set the vegetable's cooking state.
Set the number of each vegetable. This should be a number between 1 and 20.
A piped in vegetable object.
The name of a vegetable.
Write the object to the pipeline.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Set-Vegetable eggplant -cookingstate Roasted -count 5 -passthru
UPC Count Name State Color --- ----- ---- ----- ----- 4493 5 eggplant Roasted purple

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-Vegetable pepper | Set-Vegetable -cookingstate steamed

maml:description.maml:para: Simulate a PowerShell console session

This command simulates an interactive PowerShell session. It will process a text file of PowerShell commands. The function will insert your prompt and "type" out each command when you press any key. At the end of the typed command or whenever a pipe character is inserted, the script will pause. Press Enter or any key to continue. If it is the end of the command pressing Enter will execute the command.
Use the -NoExecute parameter to run through the demo without executing any commands.
Commented lines will be skipped.
Press 'q' or ESC at any pause to quit the demo.
This function will NOT run properly in the PowerShell ISE.
VARIABLE NAMES Do not use any variables in your script file that are also used in this script. These are the variables you most likely need to avoid:
$file $i $running $key $command $count
MULTI-LINE COMMANDS To use a multi-line command, in your demo file, put a :: before the first line and :: after the last line:
... Get-Date :: get-wmiobject win32_logicaldisk -filter "Drivetype=3" | Select Caption,VolumeName,Size,Freespace | format-table -autosize :: Get-Process ...
The function will simulate a nested prompt. Press any key after the last >> to execute. Avoid using the line continuation character in your demo file.

TIMING By default the function will insert a random pause interval between characters. This is a random value in milliseconds between the -RandomMinimum and -RandomMaximum parameters which have default values of 50 and 140 respectively. If you want a static or consistent interval, then use the -Pause parameter. The recommended value is 80.

SCOPE All the commands in your demo script are executed in the context of the Start-TypedDemo function. This means you have to be very aware of scope. While you can access items in the global scope like PSDrives, anything you create in the demo script will not persist.
This also means that none of the commands in your demo script will show up in PowerShell history.

COMMENTS Any line that begins with # will be treated as a comment and skipped. If you have a multi-line comment you will need to put a # at the beginning of each line. You can't use PowerShell's block comment characters.

maml:Description.maml:para: The file name of PowerShell commands to execute. It can have any extension you choose.
The typing speed interval between characters in milliseconds. The recommended value is 100.
The file name and path for a transcript session file. Existing files will be overwritten.
Do not execute any of the commands.
Simulate a new PowerShell session with the copyright header and a prompt. This works best if you start your demo from the C: drive.
The file name of PowerShell commands to execute. It can have any extension you choose.
The minimum time interval between characters in milliseconds. The default is 50.
The maximum time interval between characters in milliseconds. The default is 140.
The file name and path for a transcript session file. Existing files will be overwritten.
Do not execute any of the commands.
Simulate a new PowerShell session with the copyright header and a prompt. This works best if you start your demo from the C: drive.
The file name of PowerShell commands to execute. It can have any extension you choose.
The typing speed interval between characters in milliseconds. The recommended value is 100.
The minimum time interval between characters in milliseconds. The default is 50.
The maximum time interval between characters in milliseconds. The default is 140.
The file name and path for a transcript session file. Existing files will be overwritten.
Do not execute any of the commands.
Simulate a new PowerShell session with the copyright header and a prompt. This works best if you start your demo from the C: drive.

dev:type.maml:name: None. This only writes to the host console, not the pipeline.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Run the commands in c:\work\demo.txt using the random defaults
Run the commands in c:\work\demo.txt using a static interval of 100 milliseconds. The function will only type the commands. They will not be executed.
Run the commands in c:\work\demo.txt using the random defaults and create a transcript file.
